5.  P. T. Hanh (40107047) là 33 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.


6.  L. T. Tam (40107041) là 23 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.


7.  N. T. Soi (40107016) là 35 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.


8.  L. T. Nien  (40107013) là 30 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ Hỗ trợ Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets.

loans.name: Sarun

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarun H., is 38 years old and her husband, Mr. Pech Luk (both shown in the photo), is 43 years old, have been married since 1997 and have three children: two sons and one daughter. The family is living along national road number one, about thirty-five kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 
Sarun and her husband are farmers, they grow mangoes on their farmland in the village. She is asking for her first loan in the amount of $200 to purchase pesticide to prevent her mangoes from insects.

loans.use: To purchase pesticide to prevent mangoes from the insects.

loans.name: Mariana Judith

texts.es: Mariana Judith R. R. de 33 años de edad, posee una sala de belleza, en la cual realiza cortes de cabello, tintes, pedicure, manicure, faciales y todo lo relacionado con el cuidado de la imagen. Ella vive junto a su esposo y junto a dos hijos menores de edad. Marina coloco su propio negocio en su casa de habitación ubicada en Tonacatepeque, con el enorme deseo de mejorar la estabilidad económica de su casa, ella es una persona muy trabajadora y visionaria la cual no solo realiza diferentes tipos de servicios, sino también comercializa perfumes, tratamiento para el cuidado del cabello, peines, cremas para el cuerpo, shampoo y otros productos más, a pesar que cuenta con un año y medio de poseer su negocio, en la actualidad cuenta con varios clientes, quienes se sienten a gusto con el trabajo hecho por Mariana y por sus precios tan accesibles. Ella solicita un préstamo con el fin de poder comprar mayor cantidad de productos, así mismo introducir a su salón nuevas marcas las cuales son de mucho prestigio, con lo que desea atraer más clientes a quienes les pueda elaborar un mejor trabajo.
texts.en:
Mariana Judith R. R. is 33 years old and owns a beauty salon where she provides haircuts, coloring, pedicures, manicures, facials, and other services related to the care of one’s image. She lives with her husband and two young children. Mariana established her business at home, which is located in Tonacatepeque. With great desire she was able to improve the financial stability of her household. Being a hard worker and a visionary, Mariana sells perfumes, hair treatments, combs, body crèmes, shampoos, and other products in addition to providing different types of beauty services. Despite being in business for only a year and a half, she already has several customers who feel comfortable with her work because she has affordable prices.

Mariana is requesting a loan so that she can buy more products. She hopes to introduce to her salon new brands that are more prestigious in hopes of attracting more customers who might be in need of better service.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase beauty & personal care products

loans.name: Elmar

texts.en:
Elmar T. is from the village of Burgos. He is 36 years old. Elmar is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Elmar raises livestock, primarily pigs, for fattening and resale. Elmar has been engaged in his business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP when he sells his raised pig.

In 2010, Elmar joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Elmar is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. This will be the first loan taken out by Elmar from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.

loans.name: María Estela

texts.es: María Estela C. D. P. D. 45 años D. edad, resiD. en el municipio D. Soyapango, ubicado en el departamento D. San Salvador. Ella es madre soltera, la cual ha trabajado muy duro por sacar adelante a sus tres hijos, los cuales tienen 23, 17 y 15 años D. edad, D. los cuales el mayor trabaja, y los dos menores se dedica a estudiar. María posee un taller D. costura, el cual esta ubicado en su casa D. habitación ella elabora todo tipo D. prendas D. vestir como: blusas, pantalones, camisas, faldas y vestidos, así mismo elabora cortinas y cubrecamas. María realiza su trabajo por pedidos previos y debido a su trabajo tan bien elaborado y a todos los años D. experiencia que posee las personas confían mucho en el resultado D. su trabajo. Debido a que María es alguien quien siempre desea poder obtener más D. su trabajo ella también realiza ropa para niños, pijamas y boxers para hombres, los cuales comercializa en su casa y D. forma ambulante en diferentes mercados y departamento del país, todo con el deseo D. obtener ganancias extras para poder solventar todos los gastos del hogar. María solicita un préstamo para poder comprar tela en diferentes colores y estampados y D. esta forma elaborar más mercadería.
texts.en:
María Estela C. D. P. is 45 years old and resides in Soyapango, which is located in the Department of San Salvador. She is a single mother who works very hard so that her three children (ages 23, 17, and 15) can get ahead. María considers them to be her greatest work. The two younger children are students. She has a sewing workshop located in her house where she makes different types of garments such as blouses, trousers, shirts, skirts, and dresses. María also produces curtains and bedspreads. She receives her work through orders that are placed in advance. Since she has many years of experience and her work is well-crafted, María has earned the confidence of her customers. María is the type of person who wants to get more out of her work, so she also plans to start producing children’s clothing, pajamas, and men’s boxers. Her products are sold at home and also on the street at various markets and in different regions of the country. Everything she does is a result of her desire to earn extra income to meet all of her household expenses. María is requesting a loan in order to buy fabric in different colors and patterns so that she can produce more merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fabric

loans.name: Mansha's Group

texts.en:
Mansha is the wife of M. A. and a citizen of Borewala in Pakistan. She owns a small house of two rooms and has been living in it with her family for over fifteen years. 

A very vigorous lady, Mansha operates a clothes-selling business. She purchases the clothes from different cities and sells them in her community and market. She enjoys a good customer base because they give her orders of new fabrics in clothing. This helps her to get knowledge about the new material in clothing.  

Her husband owns & operates a grocery shop in the community. His shop is the only one in the community, which gives him good earning. Being an only shop in the community, the people's expectations become high, so he always needed of good stock in his shop. Therefore, Mansha has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband’s shop. With the loan amount he will buy groceries in bulk to meet the needs of his customers and to generate good profit from these items.

loans.use: Purchase groceries for grocery shop.

loans.name: Enkhtsetseg

texts.en: Enkhtsetseg T. is 27 years old and lives with her two daughters in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. Two years ago she became divorced from her husband. Now she lives with her two daughters, in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent, on relatives' land. Her 2 daughters are 2 and 4 years old and attend a kindergarten. Enkhtsetseg's family moved to the town from the countryside, where she was a herder. Eight years ago, she made the move in search of a better life for her family. Currently, Enkhtsetseg operates a clothing sales business at Narantuul market, the largest and most crowded market in the city. She started this business in 2003 by purchasing products in Ereen, a Chinese border city. In winter and spring time she sews children’s overcoats and coveralls. She is an open and very hardworking person. She is requesting a loan to purchase current assets.

loans.use: to increase current assets

loans.name: Mayra Jeanette

texts.es: Mayra Jeanette A. C. de 34 años de edad, reside en Ilopango, ubicado en el departamento de San Salvador. Ella posee una venta de productos desechables como platos, vasos, cucharas y tenedores, así mismo comercializa huevos, granos básicos, aceite de cocina, cremas y talcos para bebés, salsas y otros productos más. Mayra vive junto a su esposo de 36 años de edad, un hombre muy responsable con su hogar, y también vive junto a sus dos hijas menores de edad, quienes se dedican a estudiar. El negocio de Mayra esta ubicado en el mercado municipal de San Martín, siempre en el departamento de San Salvador, en donde posee su negocio desde hace 2 años, tiempo en el cual se ha ido dando a conocer y obteniendo clientes. El mayor deseo de ella es el de poder surtir aún más su negocio comprando todos los productos antes mencionados por mayor, debido a que en la zona que se encuentra ubicada, la mayoría de personas llegan a comprar en grandes cantidades con el fin de surtir negocios más pequeños como tiendas. Mayra solicita un préstamo y así de esta manera poder realizar el deseo de mejorar en su negocio, y de esta forma mejorar sus ventas y salir adelante junto a su familia.
texts.en:
Mayra Jeanette A. C. is 34 years old and resides in Illopango, which is located in the Department of San Salvador. She has a store where she sells disposable products such as plates, cups, spoons, and forks. In addition, she sells eggs, basic grains, cooking oil, lotions and talcum powder for babies, sauces, and other products. Mayra lives with her husband, who is 36 years old and a very responsible man, and their two young daughters who are enrolled in school.

Mayra’s business is located at the municipal market in San Martín, which is also in the Department of San Salvador. She has been in business for two years and during that time she has been able to create publicity and attract customers. Her greatest wish is to increase her inventory by purchasing all of her products in bulk. In the area where her business is located, most of the people who come to shop buy in large quantities to stock their own businesses, such as smaller general stores.

Mayra is requesting a loan so that she can improve her business. By increasing her sales, she will be able to move forward together with her family.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase disposable products & food items

loans.name: Davy

texts.en:
Mrs. Davy B., 22 and her husband, Mr. Saran Phorn, 22, have been married since 2008 and just have a young daughter. The family lives along National Road Number One, about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. Davy is not in the photo, her husband was available instead.

Davy is a tailor. She operates the business at home. Her husband is a security guard. She is applying for her first loan, in the amount of $500, to purchase additional fabric for her tailoring business.

loans.use: To purchase additional fabric for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Rigoberto

texts.es: Rigoberto R. F. de 54 años de edad, es una persona muy trabajadora, la cual desea salir adelante y poder contar con una vida mejor. El vive solo en el municipio de San Martín, ubicado en el departamento de San Salvador, tiene hijos pero ya todos están casados. Rigoberto se dedica a la venta de medicina popular, la cual comercializa en su casa de habitación, realiza muy buenas ventas debido a que sus casa esta ubicada en calle principal por lo que esta a la vista de muchas personas. Así mismo el comercializa su productos de forma ambulante por colonias y cantones de San Martín, el es una persona muy reconocida en su lugar de habitación, ya que desde hace 13 años que se dedica a este trabajo, por lo que él desea mejorar su negocio, es por ello que solicita un préstamo con el fin de comprar medicinas en mayores cantidades, así mismo comprar diferentes tipos de estas. Rigoberto es un señor muy amable quien posee muy buenas relaciones con sus vecinos, lo cual le permite contar con muchos clientes los cuales con mucha confianza compran sus medicinas.
texts.en:
Rigoberto R. F. is 54 years old and a hardworking individual who has the desire to succeed and have a better life. He lives alone in the town of San Martín, which is located in the Department of San Salvador. Rigoberto has children but they are all married. He sells popular medicines out of his home. Rigoberto generates very good sales since his business is located on the main street that can be seen by many people. In addition, he sells his products as a traveling merchant in the various neighborhoods and cantons of San Martín. He is well-known in the area where he lives and has been in business for 13 years.

Rigoberto wants to improve his business, so he is requesting a loan so that he can buy different types of medicines in large quantities. He is an amicable person who has good relationships with his neighbors. This allows him to attract many customers who place their trust in him when buying their medicines.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase medicines

loans.name: Saofai

texts.en:
Saofai F. is 48. She is married and has 6 children (ages 15 - 29).  She owns a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale. Saofai has 2 years of experience in this business. Saofai needs a loan of WST$1000 to purchase weed-killers, such as Gramoxome. She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 300 talas or US $125 per week) to improve and expand her business.

In 2010, Saofai joined SPBD. This is her 1st loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Saofai's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About  SPBD: 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method. Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.  

http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375"

loans.use: To purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome.

loans.name: Rin

texts.en:
Mrs. Rin S. (in the photo), 46, and her husband, Mr. Kosal Yoem, live along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong River. They have been married since 2000 and have two sons. Both of the children are still young.  

Rin has been selling porridge and Khmer noodles in front of her home for 20 years. Her husband has been selling bananas for five years. He buys them from his fellow villagers and transports them to Phnom Penh to sell in the market. Rin is requesting her first loan for $700 to help her husband purchase bananas under contract for resale.

loans.use: To purchase bananas under contract for resale.

loans.name: Mabel

texts.en: Mabel U. is 40 and married with five children, who range in age from 3 to 20. She plants and harvests bananas for sale. Mabel has three years of experience in this business. Mabel needs a loan of 1,000 Samoan tala to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 300 talas or about $125 per week) to improve/expand the business. In 2009, Mabel joined SPBD. This is her second loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Mabel's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. About SPBD In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method. Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD. http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: To purchase general farm supplies and equipment

loans.name: Dagoberto

texts.es: Dagoberto P. de 45 años de edad, reside en el departamento de Jayaque, ubicado en el departamento de La Libertad, lugar en el cual vive junto a su esposa y sus cinco hijos de 17, 15, 10, 9 y 6 años de edad. Dagoberto se dedica a hacer viajes a personas particulares, las cuales deseen dirigirse a diferentes puntos del país, el es una persona muy respetada en su lugar de habitación y así mismo es muy responsable, también muy conocido en la zona ya que cuenta con 10 años de trabajar de esta manera. Dagoberto solicita un préstamo a Integral con el deseo de contar con el dinero necesario para invertir en su automóvil y de esta manera brindarle el mantenimiento para este, así también para comprarle todos los repuestos necesario, ya que el desea poder brindar un mejor servicio, con toda la seguridad necesaria para sus clientes, de esta forma el podrá seguir contando con la confianza de las personas y las recomendaciones de ellos y así obtener más clientes. Esto último es de mucha importancia para Dagoberto ya que es el único que trabaja en su hogar, por lo que es necesario poseer trabaja diario para llevar el sustento a su casa.
texts.en:
Dagoberto P. is 45 years old and resides in Jayaque, which is located in the Department of La Libertad. He lives with his wife and five children (ages 17, 15, 10, 9, and 6). Dagoberto provides chauffeur services to individuals who want to travel to different parts of the country. He is a highly respected person in his hometown and is very responsible. Dagoberto is well-known in other parts of the area since he has been in this business for ten years.

He is requesting a loan from Apoyo Integral so that he can have the necessary funds to perform maintenance on his vehicle. Dagoberto also plans to buy all the spare parts that are needed so that he can provide the best service and safest conditions for his customers. He wants to continue earning their trust so that he can generate more recommendations and attract new customers. Since Dagoberto is the only member of his household who is working, it is necessary for him to have the means to earn a daily income so that he can support his family.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Vehicle maintenance

loans.name: Francisca Alicia

texts.es: Francisca Alicia M. D. H. D. 40 años D. edad, resiD. en Tonacatepeque, ubicado en el departamento D. San Salvador, en donD. resiD. junto a su compañero D.  vida quien se dedica a trabajar, y junto a una hija. Francisca trabaja muy duro D. lunes a domingo elaborando tortillas, las cuales son un alimento muy típico el cual forma parte D. la alimentación básica D. las personas, ya que los salvadoreños las consumen a diario hasta tres veces al día, por lo que es un negocio bastante estable, en el cual se cuenta con muchos clientes a pesar D. poseer diferente competencia. Francisca y su familia depenD. en gran manera D. las ganancias D. este negocio por lo que es D. mucha importancia poder mejorar sus ventas, es por ello que solicita un préstamo a Integral con el deseo D. comprar maíz por mayor, así mismo comprar tambos D. gas propano, esto lo hace con el deseo D. contar con la materia prima D. su negocio y así obtener mayores ganancias, las cuales sean D. mucho beneficio para su familia.
texts.en:
Francisca Alicia M. D. H. is 40 years old and resides in Tonacatepeque, which is located in the Department of San Salvador. She lives with her daughter and her husband who is dedicated to his work. From Monday to Sunday, Francisca works hard preparing tortillas since they are a basic staple of the Salvadoran diet that can be consumed up to three times a day. Even though she has plenty of competition, her business is quite stable and attracts many customers. Francisca and her family depend heavily on the income generated from her business, so it is very important that she improve her sales.

For this reason, she is requesting a loan from Apoyo Integral. She plans to buy corn in bulk as well as tanks of propane gas. Francisca hopes to have the supplies needed in her business to generate more revenue, which will be of great benefit to her family.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase corn & tanks of propane gas

loans.name: Kosar's Group

texts.en:
Kosar lives in a small city called Borewala in Pakistan with her family. She is the mother of five children, but only two of them could get an education due to financial problems.

Her husband is a truck driver and one of her sons also drives a truck. Kosar makes handmade fans to supplement her income and to support her family financially. 

She has applied for a loan from Asasah for her second son. With the loan amount, he will enhance his scrap business. He is running out of stock these days and wants to put more stock in his shop to increase his income. 

Kosar is hopeful that with the loan assistance, her son will be able to stand on his own feet and will start making a positive financial contribution to his family.

loans.use: Purchase scrap for scrap business

loans.name: Rita Faiva

texts.en: Rita Faiva N. is 36 and married with five children. She sells lavalavas (bottom-half wrap-around prints worn by both men and women). Rita has two years of experience in this business. Rita needs a loan of 1,000 Samoan tala to purchase additional fabrics and materials. She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 150 talas or about $63 per week) to improve/expand the business. In 2008, Rita joined SPBD. This is her second loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Rita's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. About SPBD In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method. Please join SPBD's lending team on Kiva to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD. http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: To purchase additional fabrics and materials

loans.name: Tupe

texts.en:
Tupe L. is 29 and married with three children (ages 2 - 6).  She owns a business of selling cooked food like sopu bones, fried chicken and cooked taro that mix with coconut cream.  Tupe has two years of experience in this business.  Tupe needs a loan of WST $1,500 to buy raw ingredients for cooked foods.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 450 talas or US $188 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2009, Tupe joined SPBD. This is her second loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Tupe's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To buy raw ingredients for cooked foods

loans.name: Parveen Akhter's Group

texts.en: Parveen akhter is a widow who lost her husband a few years ago as a result of his sudden death. She is 55 years of age and lives in Borewala, Pakistan with her four sons and two daughters. Three of her sons work to support the family while only her youngest son managed to get his education until the 5th standard. Parveen sells clothes to contribute financially to her family. Selling clothes proved very helpful for her family’s financial life.  She has applied for a loan from Asasah to help her elder son who sells fruit from a cart. With the loan, her son will buy fresh seasonal fruits, which will help him increase his income. Parveen is hopeful that with the help of this increased income, she will be able to marry her daughter who is 21 years of age.

loans.use: To purchase seasonal fruits

loans.name: Jogoo Group

texts.en:
Furaha B., age 27, is married with two children who are  5 and 3 years old.  She has had a beauty salon for eight years.  She works from 8 am to 9 pm and she is able to make a monthly profit of about $87.

This will be Furaha’s second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loan to buy salon equipment and she has paid back the loan successfully.  She hopes for a loan to buy more salon equipment. Her dream is to open a food café when she gets a bigger loan.

Furaha will share this loan with her loan group, Jogoo, which includes 16 members.  The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. 
\t
In the picture, Furaha is sitting first on the right in the front row.

loans.use: To buy salon equipment

loans.name: Rabih

texts.en: Rabih is a 31-year-old single man from Lebanon.  He has been the owner of an Internet café since 2003 with seven years of experience in this field. This is where most teenagers visit to chat and do research. Since Rabih’s work is in Southern Lebanon & most of the Lebanese leave the city for the mountains during the summer season, Rabih’s work needs to be developed to stay up to date with the necessary programs and materials. It’s the first time that Rabih has requested a loan from Al Majmoua. He will use the loan to do the necessary maintenance on his equipment and to increase the number of computers, which will increase the number of visitors per day and thus increase his income. His dream is to own a bigger place in addition to a retail showroom.

loans.use: To do maintenance on his equipment

loans.name: Kivule Group

texts.en:
Gikaro C., aged 38, is married with 4 children, aged 13, 10, 7 and 3. He has had a poultry business now for 3 years.  He works from 8am to 6pm daily and he is able to make a monthly profit of about $268.

This will be Gikaro’s 2nd loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  He used the previous loan to buy chicken feed and medicines. He has successfully paid back the loan. He hopes for a loan to buy 400,000 chicks. 

Gikaro will share this loan with his loan group,  Kivule, which totals 20 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. 

In the picture Gikaro is second from left, front row, in a white shirt.

loans.use: To buy 400,000 chicks.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith R. is from the village of  Gingoog City. She is 47 years old, married and has 2 school-aged children. Judith owns & operates a specialized retail store where she sells processed food like longganisa (pork sausage flavored with indigenous spices). She has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Judith joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Judith from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. In 2010, Melgin joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. loans.name: Robelyn

texts.en:
Mrs. Robelyn Y. is from the barangay (district) of Tabid, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 31 years old and married to Rolando Y., a sales manager of Nature Spring Water Incorporated. She is blessed with 3 young children. Robelyn is presently engaged in a business selling dried fish and longganisa (sausage). She also has another business buying and selling junk bottles, plastics and scrap metals. She additionally receives support from her husband's salary. Roselyn has been involved in these businesses for 3 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month from them.

In 2007, Robelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. An active member of PMPC under the PDP-LP, a microfinance program, Robelyn has successfully repaid a loan of 3,000 PHP. She is now requesting an amount of 5,000 PHP as her 5th loan,  to be used for additional capital for her two existing businesses. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the businesses to improve her family's general living conditions, especially in meeting their basic needs, saving for future use and the children’s education, loan repayments, insurance and possible business expansions. 

About PMPC:
 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Marieta

texts.en:
Marieta H. is a widow; she lives in Vanadzor city with her two children. Her son is a student and her daughter is a teacher of psychology in one of Vanadzor's schools. 


For about five years Marieta has run her own business: clothes and household goods trading. She also offers a photocopying service. With the profit from her business Marieta supports her family. 


Now Marieta is asking for a 600,000 AMD loan to increase her assortment of summer clothes, to buy some glassware to resell and also to buy paper for her copier.

loans.use: To increase her range of summer clothes, to buy glassware and to buy paper for her photocopier

loans.name: Cherryl's Group

While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Cherryl is married and has two infant children. To make a living, Cherryl provides motorcycle transport services. The main source of income for the business comes from operating a tricycle-transport service. Cherryl has been engaged in her business for more than six years and earns approximately 4.000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Cherryl joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cherryl is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to repair an existing vehicle for better service. This will be the first loan taken out by Cherryl from ASKI. loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth S. is a 50-year-old entrepreneur from Nyalenda Estate, a low-income residential estate off Kisumu City, along the shores of Lake Victoria. Elizabeth is a widow who has seven grown-up children aged between 18 and 32 years. She has in her custody three grandchildren who depend on her for their daily upkeep.

Elizabeth runs a charcoal-selling business in the estate and has been doing it for the last year. She makes a monthly income of 5,000 Kenyan shillings and from this business, she has been able to take care of her children and also the grandchildren under her care. 

Elizabeth has applied for a first loan of Kshs 20,000 from KADET Limited. She hopes to use this loan to buy more stock of charcoal for sale. With this amount, she is sure of buying 25 sacks of charcoal for sale. 

With the profits generated from the expanded business, she plans to take her grandchildren to good schools so that they can get a good foundation and a quality education.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal stock for sale

loans.name: Azra Parveen's Group

texts.en:
Azra parveen is 40 years old and lives in a city called Borewala in Pakistan. She is the mother of three sons; one of them works as a laborer. 
She is a housewife who does household chores and takes care of her family. 


She has applied for a loan for the first time from Asasah for her husband who wants to buy a donkey cart for his loading business.  
His old cart has become worn and it is very difficult for him to put a load on it as it cannot support heavy materials. 



Azra is hopeful that, with the help of a loan, her husband will continue his loading business which has temporarily stopped due to the bad condition of his old cart.

loans.use: to purchase a new donkey cart for a loading business

loans.name: Enkhbayar

texts.en:
Enkhbayar, S. is a humble, helpful and open-minded person. She is divorced and lives with her mother and 2 daughters in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. They all live together in a traditional Mongolian, nomadic tent. Her oldest daughter, Sodgerel, is 10 years old and attends secondary school. Her younger daughter, Khulan, is 5 years old and stays at home with her grandmother. 


Enkhbayar operates a taxi service in her town. She enjoys transporting people. She says, “I must be very responsible and careful when driving my car in order to provide a safe ride for my customers”. Also, she says, “The most important thing to me is to provide a good education for my children". 



She is requesting a loan to purchase four tires and other spare parts for her car.

loans.use: to purchase four tires and other spare parts for her car

Claudio has been engaged in his business for over 12 years and earns approximately 9,500 PHP a month.

In 2009, Claudio joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Claudio has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. He is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & provide working capital. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Claudio from HSPFI. loans.name: Kisa Kya Maria Womens Group- Kayunga

texts.en: S. David William is married with a family of four. He has been operating a retail shop in Ntenjeru, Kayunga where he has been selling mostly general merchandise for over three years. He has been trading in a variety of products commonly used for domestic use like sugar, soap, salt, cooking oil, paraffin and much more merchandise, earning him a profit of 70,000 Ugandan shillings per week. S. was encouraged by his brother-in-law to join the business. He began by selling agricultural produce. This hard working gentleman also earns extra profits from banana sales, milk sales and a rental business. Ever since he began operating his retail shop, he says he has faced the problem of a limited stock of products in his shop that cannot satisfy the customers' demands. Therefore, David is looking forward to increasing the retail stock in his business when he gets this loan and expanding into a wholesale shop. This, he says, will help him earn more revenue and live within the means of his business as he envisions improving his family’s standard of living and further educating his children.

loans.use: To buy more retail stock for his business

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda is a widow with six children and none of the children goes to school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. She plans to use this loan to buy more foodstuffs like bunches of bananas, yams, cassava, sweet potatoes, beef and chicken. She has houses for rent as an additional income. She has been in this business for many years.  Besides this restaurant business,  she also owns a stall of raw food  near her restaurant.  

Her business challenges include the rainy season and defaulters. She hopes to see her business expand and open more branches of restauranst  Imelda joined MCDT because she wanted additional capital for her  resturant  business. She works six days a week and resides in and owns a four-roomed house that has electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include food and medication.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas, yams, cassava, sweet potatoes, beef and chicken

loans.name: Flordelina

texts.en:
Flordelina P. is a widow who lives in Purok Kasoy, Brgy. Tabugon, Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  a general store and a mobile vending businesses.  Her only child is 28 years old. 

Flordelina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2001 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 19 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Flordelina has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 29,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 20th loan, she is borrowing PHP 29,500, which she intends to use as additional capital for the development of her business, to provide for their basic needs and continue to save for the future.  Flordelina P. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Fabian

texts.en:
Fabian M. is from the town of Talibon. He is 70 years old. Fabian is married and has nine adult children. To make a living, Fabian owns & operates a fishing boat to catch and sell assorted fish in he market. Fabian has been engaged in his business for over 30 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Fabian joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Fabian has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Fabian is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to repair his fishing boat. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but savings, insurance, and training, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

Purita aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the  Dungganon way. 

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The Kiva borrower is a 31-year-old Lebanese married man and has one child. He has more than 20 years of experience running a car repair shop and he is specialized in car body repair. He also supports his life income by working in car spare parts. From his business income, he was able over the years to generate enough income to cover his family's expenses. He is requesting to borrow $1,700 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase new tools for his work in addition of buying more spare parts for his business. This is his second loan from a Kiva partner and he has been reliable with his payments and paid in full several months early. And he was thankful for the loan and he is certain that the new loan will help him expand his business level even further.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.). Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:
Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese Microfinance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in Microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: To purchase new tools for his work in addition of buying more spare parts.

Lydia is into a restaurant business and has been in it for seven years. She started by selling secondhand clothes and then later changed to her restaurant business. The biggest challenge she has is that her customers eat on credit and then default on the payment.
 
Lydia expects, in future to, acquire a TV, a fridge and a fan for her business. However, her family goal is to build her own home and stop renting. The purpose of the loan is to buy a plot of land to build on.

About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients, but also has savings, insurance, and training programs, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Kasifa

texts.en:
Kasifa is a single mother of two children and her children go to school.  She also takes care of her mother and her grand children. She owns a stall in Kalerwe market selling second hand clothes.  Kasifa wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second hand clothes.   She buys bales of clothes from Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda, and uses public transport to and from shopping.    She has been in this clothing business for ten years.  Besides this clothing business she sells piped water from her home.   

Kasifa stays in Mulago Zone in Kawempe Division and works six days a week.  Her business challenges include transportation and defaulters.  She aspires to buy a plot of land.  She decides to join MCD T to acquire enough capital  for her clothing business.  Kasifa resides in and owns a four roomed house and the family has access to electricity and piped water.  Her monthly expense includes food and school fees.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The Kiva borrower is a 37-year-old married woman from Lebanon and a mother of 3 school-age children. She has operated an established  tailoring business from her home for the last 15 years. She makes all kind of clothes, pants, shirts, robes etc. and offers clothes repair services to her customers. Over the years, she was able to help her husband with the household expenses and to pay for her children schooling. Today, she is requesting a loan of $600 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase more textiles needed to meet the needs of her clients. She specifically notes that she will be able to deliver more designs and a greater variety of textile brand to her customers. 

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:
Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese Microfinance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in Microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: To purchase more supplies of textiles

loans.name: Benkadi I Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe BENKADI I  est composé  de femmes mariées du village de  Sokan dans la préfecture de San, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 34 ans et au moins 5 enfants.
Elles cultivent essentiellement de l’arachide. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne.
SETOU D., la présidente du groupe, compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants, au grand marché de Kimparana. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Kimparana, M’peresso et  dans les  marchés  environnants en détail (souvent en gros) au comptant à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe  comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 35 000 FCFA qui sera  utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses  courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The group, Benkadi I, is made up of married women from the village of Sokan in the San prefecture, a region of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional families. They are on average 34 years old and have at least 5 children. They mainly grow peanuts. In order to make their agricultural businesses more profitable, the members of the group decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program 3 years ago. After having fully paid back their previous loans, they are on their third farm loan. Setou D., the president of the group, expects to use her loan to buy a sufficient quantity of peanut seeds, small tools and material inputs at the large market in Kimparana. After the rainy season, the crops are stored for a certain amount of time so that they may be valued before being sold at the large market in Kimparana, M'peresso and on the surrounding markets at retail (often at wholesale) for cash to a customer base largely coming from big cities. After the sale of their agricultural products, the members of the group each expects to make a profit of 35,000 FCFA, which will be used to repay the interest on their loans and the everyday expenses of the family.

Translated from French by Martha Schmitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of material inputs, seeds, and small tools.

loans.name: Kiden

texts.en:
Kiden M., on the right in the photo, sells bread, ice cream and groundnut phase (peanut paste) at the market and is requesting a loan to stock tomatoes, onions, etc., to sell.

Kiden M. is 39 years old and is married to a peasant. She has three children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To stock tomatoes, onions, etc., to sell

loans.name: Hasmik

texts.en:
Hasmik T. was born in 1966 and is married with three children. She lives in Ijevan city and, since 2007, she has been engaged in selling fruits and vegetables. Her husband and one of her sons help her in this business and, thanks to the income from the business, they have supported their family, bought necessary furniture for their home, and bought a small car for delivering fruits and vegetables.

Now Hasmik and her family intend to increase their business, so they need bigger vehicle for delivery. They already sold their small car, but the proceeds from the car’s sale isn't enough to buy a delivery truck. So they need a 350,000 AMD loan to add to the sale proceeds to buy a delivery truck. This truck will allow them to bring more fruits and vegetables from villages to their business place in Ijevan city.

loans.use: To buy a delivery truck for her business

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en: Nenita J. is from the village of San Roque, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 49 years old and is married with three adult children. Nenita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Nenita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. loans.name: Benkadi Ii Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe BENKADI II  est  constitué  de femmes mariées du village de Sokan de la préfecture de San, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali), qui  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles et  qui ont en moyenne 36 ans et au moins 4 enfants.
Elles cultivent essentiellement de l’arachide. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe  ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis 3 ans. 
Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne.
BINTOU M., qui est la présidente du groupe, compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels agricoles et des intrants, au grand marché de Kimparana. Après l’hivernage, sa récolte est  stockée pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elle ait de la valeur avant d’être vendue  au grand marché de Kimparana en détail (souvent en gros) au comptant à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Tandis que les  autres membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice  de 30 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille, BONTOU M.  elle, espère avoir  55000FCFA .
texts.en:
The group Benkadi II is made up of married women from the village of Sokan in the San prefecture, a region of Ségou (fourth administrative reion of the Republic of Mali), who live in traditional families and who, on average, are 36 years old and have at least 4 children. They all grow peanuts. In order to make their agricultural businesses more profitable, the members of the group decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program 3 years ago. After having fully paid back their previous loans, they are on their third farm loan. Bintou M., who is the president of the group, expects to use her loan to buy a sufficient quantity of peanut seeds, small tools and material inputs at the large market in Kimparana. After the rainy season, the crops are stored for a certain time so that they may be valued before being sold at the large market in Kimparana at retail (often at wholesale) for cash to a customer base largely coming from big cities. While the other group members each expect to make a profit of 30,000 FCFA after the sale of their agricultural products, which will be used to pay the interest on the loan and for the everyday needs of the family, Bontou M. expects a profit of 55,000 FCFA.

Translated from French by Martha Schmitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of material inputs, seeds, and small tools.

He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of his family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. She is the mother of six children and her two sons work with their father at his scrap shop. She has four daughters who are all getting their education.

Azra is a second year member of Asasah. Last year she received a loan for her sewing business which has giving her good earnings. This year she has applied for a loan for her husband’s scrap business which is out of stock these days, preventing him from generating income for the family.

Azra is hopeful that this loan will be as profitable as the previous one.

loans.name: Benkadi Iv Group

texts.fr:
BENKADI IV  est composé de femmes mariées du village de Sokan de la préfecture de San, région de Ségou,  qui vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 30 ans, au moins 4 enfants et  cultivent  de l’arachide. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis 3 ans. 
Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne.
GNIRI C., compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants, au grand marché de Kimparana. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Kimparana, M’Pèrèsso et  dans les  marchés  environnants en détail (souvent en gros) au comptant à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe BENKADI IV comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 25.000 à 40 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Benkadi IV group is composed of married women from the village of Sokan in the San prefecture, in the Segou Region (the fourth administrative region of Mali). The women live in traditional families. They are on the average 30 years old , have at least four children, and cultivate peanuts. In order to make their agricultural work profitable, three years ago they have decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso credit program. After having duly repaid previous loans, they are now on their first agricultural loan. Gniri C. plans to use her loan to purchase a sufficient supply of peanut seeds, small tools and agricultural inputs, at the big market in Kimparana. After the winter season, the harvest is stored for a while as its price increases, before being sold at the big market of Kimparana and other nearby markets, retail (often wholesale) for cash to customers mostly coming from big towns. After selling their produce, members of the Benkadi IV group plan to obtain an income, between 25,000 and 40,000 West African francs each, which will be used to pay off the loan interest and cover ongoing family expenses.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing agricultural inputs, seeds and small tools

This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. V.'s son appears in the photograph with his fishing tools.

loans.name: 03.01.34-Dien Bien Group

texts.en: Huyen H. T. (166) is a 29-year-old femaL. living in the town of Thanh Hoa. Huyen is the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women, a Kiva partner. WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 34-Dien Bien (03.01.34 Điện Biên). Huyen is married and has two infant children. To making a living, Huyen operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling clothing and shoe products in the local community. Huyen has been engaged in this business for more than four years and earns approximately 2.400.000 Vietnamese dong (VND) a month from it. In 2010, Huyen joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Huyen is requesting for the first time a loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women of 4.248.000 VND, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. Huyen plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it. About the other borrowers in the group: 1. T. T. Hien (163) is a 48-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 4248000 VND loan to support her general store. 2. L. T. Dap (164) is a 52-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 4248000 VND loan to support her clothing business. 3. N. T. Dieu (165) is a 60-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 4248000 VND loan to support her clothing business. About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. Huyen H. T. (166) là 29 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoa. Huyen là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 4 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 34-Dien Bien (03.01.34 Điện Biên). Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ bán áo quần & giày dép trong cộng đồng địa phương. Huyen thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 4 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Huyen kiếm được khoảng 2.400.000 VND. Vào 2010, Huyen đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. Huyen đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 4.248.000 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 1st khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. T. T. Hien (163) là 48 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4248000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hàng bách hóa. 2. L. T. Dap (164) là 52 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4248000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh quần áo. 3. N. T. Dieu (165) là 60 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4248000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh quần áo. Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa. *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva. ."
