texts.en:
Teddy is married and has two children; one of them is at school and the second one is still young.  She doesn’t take care of additional family members. Teddy rents a two-room house which has electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include rent, medication and food.

Teddy owns a bar in Nakulabye where she sells all types of liquors and beers.  She wants to use this loan to buy more crates of beer and jerycans of local gin. She doesn’t have any side job. She has been in this business for many years. She rents her business premises and sells to all categories of people, both retail and wholesale . She works seven days in a week and depends on this job for a living. Her business challenges are thieves and defaulters.

loans.use: To buy more gin and beer

loans.name: Mheadel

texts.en:
Mheadel S. is from the village of Sta. Cruz. He is 19 years old. Mheadel is single. To make a living, Mheadel owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting corn for sale. Mheadel has been engaged in his business for over 2 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Mheadel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mheadel is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Mheadel from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our field partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Phun

texts.en:
Phun S., 26, is married and resides with her husband and child in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. 

S. sells groceries for an income of USD 2.50 per day. Her husband sells various kinds of fish from fishermen, earning an income of USD 3 per day. 

S. is requesting a loan of USD 750 to purchase pigs and more groceries to stock her store. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy pigs and more groceries to stock her store

loans.name: Benkadi Vi Group

texts.fr:
BENKADI VI  est un regroupement de femmes mariées du village de Sokan de la préfecture de San, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 32 ans, au moins 6 enfants et cultivent  de l’arachide. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne.
FANTA N. compte utiliser son pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants, exclusivement  au grand marché de Kimparana ville. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de M’Pèrèsso et  dans les  marchés  environnants en détail (souvent en gros) au comptant à une clientèle composé de revendeurs.
Les membres du groupe BENKADI VI comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 20 000 à 25 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Benkadi VI group is composed of married women from the village of Sokan in the San prefecture, in the Segou Region (the fourth administrative region of Mali). The women live in traditional families. They are on the average 32 years old, have at least six children, and cultivate peanuts. In order to make their agricultural work profitable, three years ago they have decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso credit program. After having duly repaid previous loans, they are now on their third agricultural loan. Fanta N. plans to use her loan to purchase an ample supply of peanut seeds, small tools and agricultural inputs, at the big market in the town of Kimparana. After the winter season, the harvest is stored for a while as its price increases, before being sold at the big market of M’Pèrèsso and other nearby markets, retail (often wholesale) for cash to a customer base composed of resellers. After selling their produce, members of the Benkadi VI group plan to obtain an income, between 20,000 and 25,000 West African francs each, which will be used to pay off the loan interest and cover ongoing family expenses.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing agricultural inputs, seeds and small tools

loans.name: Basem

texts.en:
Basem, who appears in the photograph, is a 21-year-old young man from Tulkarem. Basem's family members have been farmers for a long time. Basem had to leave school and join his father in working and taking care of the family. Two of Basem's brothers are government employees and they help with the family's expenses.

Basem, who is regretting leaving school, is engaged now and needs a $2,400 loan to cover some of the wedding expenses. Basem decided that he will take another loan after repaying the current one so he can resume his education. He believes that education will help him get a good job and, in addition to working on the farm with his father, will improve his financial situation.

loans.use: Cover wedding expenses

loans.name: Ye

texts.en: Ye P., 31, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. P. is employed at a local garment factory for an income of USD 2 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of USD 4.75 per day. P. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to repair the house. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to open a tailor shop.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To repair the house.

loans.name: Belinda

texts.en:
Belinda J. is from the town of Talibon. She is 34 years old. Belinda is single. To make a living, Belinda owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. She recently started selling ready-to-wear clothes and hopes to be able to expand her new venture. Belinda has been engaged in her business for over 10 years.

Belinda joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Belinda has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Belinda is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 17th loan taken out by Belinda from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Prak

texts.en: Prak S., 54, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. S. and her husband produce traditional baskets to sell for an income of USD 2.50 each per day. S. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a plot of farmland to expand the family farming business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a plot of farmland to expand the farming business.

loans.name: Leng

texts.en: Leng S., 20, is married and resides with her husband and a child in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. S. is a tailor and earns an income of USD 2.00 each per day. Her husband is a driver for a farm in the province, earning an income of USD 4.50 per day to help cover the family's expenses. S. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase a plot of farmland to expand the family farming business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a plot of farmland.

loans.name: Hong

texts.en: Hong T., 37, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. T. sells meatballs and cooked fish for a gross income of USD 40 per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of USD 10 per day. T. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase more fish to produce more meatballs to sell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her sixth loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more fish to produce more meatballs.

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina is married to a storekeeper for Roko Construction Company and they have four children. All of them are at school and she doesn’t take care of additional family members. Regina owns a retail shop in Kawempe, selling all types of merchandise like sugar, salt, soap, cooking oil, and dry cells.

She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of sugar, jerrycans of cooking oil, boxes of bathing and washing soap, cartons of salt, in order to add more stock in the business. She has no additional income She has been in this business for the last nineteen years. She operates her business from the shop and her customers are people in the area. She works seven days a week. She depends on this job for a living. Her challenge is the transportation of merchandise from Kikuubo to her business premises in Kawempe. Regina uses public transport to and from shopping and goes for shopping once a week. Her monthly expenses are school fees and food. She resides in and owns a three roomed house and the family has access to electricity and not to piped water.

loans.use: To buy more bags of sugar, boxes of washing and bathing soap, dry cells, and cartons of salt.

loans.name: Luciano

texts.en:
Luciano M. is from the town of Talibon. He is 49 years old. Luciano is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Luciano owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling gasoline and petroleum in the local community. Luciano has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month for these activities.

Luciano joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luciano has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Luciano is requesting a new loan of 18,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell and new items like rice, corn, sugar, etc. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Luciano from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to their house. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell like rice, corn, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Heang

texts.en: Heang T., 59, is married and resides with her husband and five children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. T. sells porridge and a type of traditional cake for a gross income of USD 20 per day. T. is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase a motorbike for the family's use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for the family's use.

loans.name: Benkadi Vii Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe BENKADI VII  est composé  de femmes mariées du village de Sokan dans la préfecture de San, région de Ségou. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles, ont en moyenne 32 ans, au moins 6 enfants et  cultivent  de l’arachide. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe Benkadi VII ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne.
SALIMATA S. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants pour la culture,  au grand marché de Kimparana. Après l’hivernage, sa récolte est  stockée pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elle ait de la valeur avant d’être vendue  au grand marché de  M’Pèrèsso en détail (souvent en gros) au comptant à une clientèle constituée de revendeurs venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe BENKADI VII comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 20 000 à 25 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Benkadi VII group is composed of married women from the village of Sokan in the San prefecture, in the Segou Region (the fourth administrative region of Mali). The women live in traditional families. They are on the average 32 years old , have at least six children, and cultivate peanuts. In order to make their agricultural work profitable, three years ago they have decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso credit program. After having duly repaid previous loans, they are now on their third agricultural loan. Salimata S. plans to use her loan to purchase a sufficient supply of peanut seeds, small tools and agricultural inputs, at the big market in Kimparana. After the winter season, the harvest is stored for a while as its price increases, before being sold at the big market of M’Pèrèsso, retail (often wholesale) for cash to a customer base composed of resellers mostly coming from big towns. After selling their produce, members of the Benkadi VII group plan to earn between 20,000 and 25,000 West African francs each, which will be used to pay off the loan interest and cover ongoing family expenses.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing agricultural inputs, seeds and small tools

loans.name: Sem

texts.en: Sem S., 47, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. S. sells traditional medicine for an income of USD 1.00 each per day. Her husband is employed at local garment factory worker, earning an income of USD 2.00 per day. S. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase a motorbike for the family's use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for the family's use.

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma is married and has three children. She established her grocery shop a few years ago. She uses her savings to help her husband pay their household expenses. Norma received several loans from FATEN and repaid all of them on time.

Norma needs to have a good income because she has a young daughter who is disabled and has special needs, and who needs a lot of attention and medical treatment that increase the family’s expenses.

Norma needs the loan to buy new products for her shop. In the photograph, she appears in her shop.

loans.use: Purchase products

loans.name: Deomida

texts.en:
Deomida C. is from the town of Talibon. She is 62 years old. Deomida is married and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Deomida owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Deomida has been engaged in her business for over 6 years. She dreams of her businss prospering.

Deomida joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Deomida has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Deomida is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Deomida from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to their house. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Danilo

texts.en:
Danilo V. is from the village of Burgos. He is 42 years old. Danilo is married. To make a living, Danilo owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Danilo has been engaged in his business for over 12 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP whenever he sells his raised animal.

In 2010, Danilo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Danilo is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and then sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Danilo from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our field partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and then sell

loans.name: Jiguiseme I Group

texts.fr:
Les  membres du groupe JIGUISEME I   sont des femmes mariées du village de Kampogosso Kafonon dans la préfecture de San, qui   vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies. Elles ont en moyenne 34 ans, au moins 5 enfants et  cultivent  de l’arachide. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe JIGUISEME I de Kampogosso Kafonon ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne.
KARIA D. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants, exclusivement  au grand marché de Kimparana. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Kimparana. Les ventes se font en détail (souvent en gros) au comptant à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 25 000 à 35 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of the group JIGUISEME I are married women from the village of Kampogosso Kafonon, in San prefecture.  They live in traditional extended families and average 34 years of age and 5 children each.  The group members grow peanuts.  Concerned with making their crops profitable, they decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso three years ago.  After having properly repaid the previous loans, they are now on their third farm loan.  Karia D. plans on using her loan for buying a sufficient quantity of peanut seeds, sundry equipment and some supplies exclusively at the big market of Kimparana.  After the winter, the harvests are stored for a while, so that they increase in value.  They are then sold retail (often in bulk) for cash to a customer base generally from the big cities.  After selling their produce, the group members each plan on making a profit of 25,000 to 35,000 francs CFA that will be used for repaying the loan interest and for covering common family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying supplies, seeds, and equipment

loans.name: Edmundo

texts.en:
Edmundo C. is from the town of Talibon. He is 48 years old. Edmundo is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Edmundo owns and operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from operating a fishing boat to catch and sell assorted fish to the market. He works hard to earn more and be able to support his children's education.

Edmundo joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edmundo is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fishing equipment, including hooks and nets. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Edmundo from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement his family's income. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, CEVI has numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our field partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment, including hooks and nets

loans.name: Kosol

texts.en: Mrs. Kosol T. was born in 1987, lives in Roluos village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns two-hectare plot of land where she is able growing rice to sell to support her family. Now she has some problem because her field is far away from irrigation system. So to improve her face problem, Mrs. Kosol T. is requesting for a loan to buy a pump machine and rest of the loan she buys gasoline, fertilizer, and pesticide. Her husband, Mr. Seyha Toem, is a fisherman and he is also a laborer who can earn a little income to support his family. Through this activity, they support two children whom all are too small to work or study. Her husband is taken the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy a pump machine

loans.name: El Hadj Fallou

texts.fr: Monsieur ElHadj Fallou N. est un célibataire âgé de 26 ans. Il fut un apprenti maçon  avant de gérer sa propre boutique.  D’ailleurs c’est avec l’aide de sa tante qu’il est devenu boutiquier,  un métier moins fatiguant pour lui,  et espére devenir un jour un grand commerçant très connu dans le pays. Il souhaitait un prêt de 75 000 FCFA pour s'approvisionner en produits alimentaires (sucre, lait…….)
texts.en:
Mr. El Hadj Fallou N. is a 26-year old single man. He was an apprentice builder before managing his own shop. It was his aunt who helped him to become a shop owner, a trade which is less tiring for him. He hopes one day to become an important businessman who is well known in his country. He would like a loan of 75,000FCFA in order to stock up on food products (sugar, milk....)

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To stock up on goods

loans.name: Jiguiseme Ii Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe JIGUISEME II  est composé  de  10 femmes mariées du village de Kampogosso Kafonon, de San, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali) qui  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 34 ans, au moins 5 enfants et cultivent  de l’arachide. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les deux prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne.
Ester D. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants,  au grand marché de Kimparana. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Kimparana, et  dans les  marchés  environnants en détail (souvent en gros) au comptant à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe  comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 25 000 à 55 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The group Jiguiseme II is composed of ten married women from the village of Kampogosso Kafonon, in San prefecture, Segou region (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  They live in traditional families and average 34 years of age and at least five children.  The group members grow peanuts.  Concerned with making their crops profitable, they decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso three years ago.  After having properly repaid the two previous loans, they are now on their third farm loan. Ester D. plans on using her loan for buying a sufficient quantity of peanut seeds, sundry equipment, and some supplies at the big market of Kimparana and at surrounding markets.  After the winter, the harvests are stored for a while, so that they acquire some value.  They are then sold retail (often in bulk) for cash to a customer base generally from the big cities.  After selling their produce, the group members each plan on making a profit of 25,000 to 55,000 francs CFA. The profits will be used for repaying the loan interest and for covering common family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying supplies, seeds, and equipment

loans.name: Hann

texts.en: Mrs. Hann Y. was born in 1973 and she lives in Daeum Pou village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Sorphorn Men, are farmers who own two point eight-hectare plot of land where she can grow rice to sell to support their family yearly and they are also own an agric machine. Now they have some problem because it is time to grow rice, but they did have money to support. So to improve production, Mrs. Hann Y. is seeking for a loan to buy rice seed, fertilizer, pesticide, and rest of the loan she buys gasoline to support her agric machine. She is a mother of four children, two of whom are seamstresses in garment factory, while the others are studying in school. Her husband is taken the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy rice seed, fertilizer, pesticide

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph M. is thirty-two years old. He is married and has one child, who is four years old. He describes himself as outgoing.

His business is located at Masai Market, a busy market in Kisumu town. He sells curios to the local and international tourists. He has been in this business for the last six years. He says that this business is profitable but the major challenge is that local people are not keen to buy such things as curios; foreigners are mainly the ones who buy more. However he works very hard to keep his business doing well. 

He is using his loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more materials to make artifacts to expand his business.

loans.use: To buy materials to create additional curios to sell

loans.name: Nhem

texts.en:
Nhem C., 50, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. 

C. and her husband are farmers who grow rice for an income of USD 1 each per day. C. is requesting a loan of USD 200 to purchase rice seeds and fertilizer to improve her family's farming business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy rice seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Dante

texts.en:
Dante S. is a 42-year-old entrepreneur from Maricaban, Pasay City. He lives with his wife Anna, 44, and their two children.

Dante owns and manages a computer shop catering to Internet surfers, gamers, and even students. He has been in this business for eight years and has six employees. Dante makes P50,000 a month. He enjoys dealing with customers of all ages and from different walks of life. Customer traffic peaks on weekends, he says.

Dante joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2007 and has since been enjoying many benefits from being a member. He is currently in need of funds to buy computer units and upgrade some of his PC units. To continue the operation of his business, he is applying for a Php 50,000 loan.

Dante optimistically claimed that it will not be long before he will be opening his second branch.


About CCT
The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. CCT serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

loans.use: To buy computer units and upgrade some PC units

loans.name: Massamba

texts.fr: Monsieur Massamba S. est un laveur dans une station d’essence de la place.  A la station, il se fait beaucoup d’amis , de connaissances.  Il s’est profité  et les place des produits du genre parfum, tee shirt et pantelons.  Ce qui lui fait entrer dans le petit commerce. Ainsi, il souhaitait un financement de 75 000 FCFA pour acheter des marchandises.
texts.en:
Mr. Massamba S. washes cars in a local petrol station. He has made many friends and acquaintances at the station and he has taken advantage of this in order to sell them products such as perfume, T-shirts and trousers. This has allowed him to build up a small business. As such, he would like a loan of 75,000FCFA in order to buy goods.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of goods

loans.name: Erlyn

texts.en:
Erlyn S. has been able to sustain her business of selling processed food through the previous loan she received from KIVA lenders. She has repaid the whole amount of the loan she received, and the small profit she earned has added to her husband’s income from fishing. With that, she has been able to pay for the education of her five children as well as for their other basic needs allowing them to enjoy life in a simple way

Erlyn S. would like to request a larger loan for the sustainability and growth of her previous business as well as for her new venture -- a  "sari-sari" store. Sari-sari stores basically sell small quantities of various foodstuff, grocery items and beverages. “Sari” is a native Antiquenos word for variety. This is a small store that is either attached to the owner’s house or in a small native cottage not far away from the owner’s house. Such stores are convenient for people in the village who live far from the market town. 

Erlyn is determined to improve her business as well as the life of her family. Knowing that she can access financial support through loans has given her courage and faith that someday all of her five children, aged between eight and 16, will graduate from college and be ready to face their own lives.

loans.use: To purchase foods for resale through her "sari-sari" store..

loans.name: Jiguiseme Iv Group

texts.fr:
JIGUISEME IV  est regroupement de femmes mariées du village de Kampogosso Kafonon dans la préfecture de San, région de Ségou, qui  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 37 ans, au moins 7 enfants et cultivent  de l’arachide. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne. 
 TANTIO C., la présidente du groupe, compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants, au grand marché de Kimparana. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Kimparana. Les ventes se fond aussi dans les  marchés  environnants en détail (souvent en gros) au comptant à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 25 000 à 30 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
JIGUISEME IV is a group of married women from the village of Kampogosso Kafonon in the prefecture of San, in the region of Ségou. They live in traditional families. They are, on average, 37 years old and have at least seven children. They cultivate peanuts. In hopes of increasing profits from their agricultural work, the members of the group decided three years ago to participate in the loan program through Soro Yiriwaso. After having properly repaid their previous loans, they are now on their third business loan. Tantio C., the leader of the group, plans to use her loan to buy an adequate quantity of peanut seeds, small tools, and fertilizer at the main market of Kimparana. After the winter season, the crops are stored for a length of time so that their value will increase before being sold at the main market of Kimparana. They also make their sales in neighboring markets at retail (and often at wholesale), in cash, to customers who generally come from large cities. The members of the group each plan to earn, after the sale of their agricultural products, a profit of 25,000 to 30,000 FCFA which will be used to pay the interest on the loan and to meet daily family expenses.

Translated from French by Shannon Arnold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of fertilizer, seeds and small equipment

loans.name: Lagrimas

texts.en: Lagrimas is 60 years old and lives with her husband and her two children in Talim Island in the province of Rizal. She has been dedicating herself to the fishing business since she joined ASHI in 2005, but years ago she also started a hog-fattening business. This is how she earns a good income. She can also count on the help of her husband and her two children. As this business has proved to be profitable, she will keep on running it, as her aim is to increase her working principal. She will be very responsible with her payments and she is thankful to all Kiva lenders who will support the loan she is requesting. The loan will be used to buy more piglets, feed, and vitamins, and also to purchase raw materials for her fishing business. The capital will fund further expansion of the family ventures and support her dreams for her family to have a decent way of life. Lagrimas is a hard-working entrepreneur who is always looking for opportunities to grow. Through her daily effort, she is giving hope to her family.

loans.use: To buy more piglets, feeds and vitamins, and raw materials for her fishing business, and increase her working capital.

loans.name: Papa Meissa

texts.fr: Monsieur Pape Meissa F. est un chauffeur de métier mais s’active également dans le petit commerce pour diversifier ses revenus. Il voudrait un prêt de 150 000 FCFA pour développer son petit commerce. Il vend en fait des draps de lit à travers ses connaissances. Il est âgé de 47 ans et exerce ce commerce depuis 2 ans.
texts.en:
Mr. Pape Meissa F. is a driver by profession, but also has a small business in order to diversify his revenues. He would like a loan of 150,000FCFA in order to develop this small business. In fact he sells bed sheets through his aquaintances. He is 47 years old and has been carrying out this business for two years.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase bed sheets

loans.name: Samit

texts.en: Mrs. Samit Y. and her family are living in Daeum Pou village in Takeo province. She was born in 1977 who is a farmer who owns three-hectare plot of land where she can earn some money to support her family while her husband, Mr. Phoeurn Nak, is a horse cart driver who can also earn some money to support his family. Now she has some problem because her field is time to do farming, but she did not have enough money to support. So to improve current production, Mrs. Samit Y. is seeking for a loan to purchase rice seed and rest of the loan she hires farming laborers to help her to do farming. She is a mother of four children whom all are studying in school and helping their parents’ businesses. Her husband is taken the photo with her.

loans.use: To purchase rice seed

loans.name: Mikayel

texts.en: Mikayel V. is 28 years old and lives in Khashtarak village, Ijevan area, with his parents. Mikayel works as a contract serviceman for the Ministry of Defense's system. At the same time Mikayel and his family are engaged in cattle-breeding, swine breeding, bee-keeping and land cultivation. In their farm they have two cows, two calves, two pigs, four rabbits, some hens and turkey hens, and five beehives. With incomes from farming Mikayel and his family solve their everyday needs and they hope to increase their farm in future. Mikayel asks for a 350,000 AMD loan to buy fodder for his farm animals.

loans.use: To buy fodder for his farm animals

loans.name: Jiguiseme V Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe JIGUISEME V  sont des femmes mariées du village de Kampogosso Kafonon dans de SAN, région de Ségou, qui  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies, ayant  en moyenne 32 ans,  5 enfants et cultivent  de l’arachide. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne.
MAMOU YACOUBA D. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants,  au grand marché de Kimparana. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Kimparana. Les ventes se fond aussi dans les  marchés  environnants en détail (souvent en gros) au comptant à une clientèle composée de consommateurs et de revendeurs venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 30 000 à 55 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of the group JIGUISEME V are married women from the village of Kampogosso Kafonon in the prefecture of San, in the region of Ségou, who live in extended traditional families. They are, on average, 32 years old and have five children. They cultivate peanuts. In hopes of increasing the profits from their agricultural work, the members of the group decided three years ago to participate in the loan program through Soro Yiriwaso. After having properly repaid their previous loans, they are now on their third business loan. Mamou Yacouba D. plans to use her loan to buy an adequate quantity of peanut seeds, small tools, and fertilizer at the main market of Kimparana. After the winter season, the crops are stored for a length of time so that their value will increase before being sold at the main market of Kimparana. They also make their sales in neighboring markets at retail (and often at wholesale), in cash, to customers who generally come from large cities. The members of the group each plan to earn, after the sale of their agricultural products, a profit of 30,000 to 55,000 FCFA which will be used to pay the interest on the loan and to meet daily family expenses.

Translated from French by Shannon Arnold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of fertilizer, seeds, and small equipment

loans.name: Hadjah

texts.en: Hadjah is married  to a business man and they have seven children, all of whom are at school. She plans to use the loan to buy more bunches of bananas. She has been in this business for the last eight years. She does not have any additional income. She works in Kawempe market selling bananas. Her major business challenge is transportation. She buys bunches of bananas from Mbarara and Masaka Districts and uses public transport to and from Masaka. Hadjah works seven days a week and aspires to see her business grow so she can start selling wholesale. She joined MCDT because it was helping poor women get a living. Her monthly expenses include food and school fees. She rents a two-roomed house which has electricity but no piped water.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Rem

texts.en: Mrs. Rem S. is married to Mr. Sophana Long both of them are living in Daeum Pou village in Takeo province. She was born in 1985. She and her husband are farmers who own two point five-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support their family and a side from farming her husband is also a fisherman and motorbike taxi driver. Now this couple has some problem because their field is time to do farming, but they did not have enough money to grow. So to improve production, Mrs. Rem S. is requesting for a loan to buy rice seed, fertilizer, pesticide, and gasoline. She is a mother of two children, one of whom is enrolled in local public school, while the youngest one is three years old. Her husband is taken the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy rice seed, fertilizer, pesticide, and gasoline

loans.name: Meissa

texts.fr:
Voilà 15 ans que Monsieur Meissa D. fait du commerce après une courte expérience d’apprenti chauffeur. La vente de mil, arachide ou de niébé l’intéresse le plus et il les place en gros à ses clients. 
Agé de 44 ans, Monsieur D. est à sa deuxième demande de crédit et sollicitait 250 000 FCFA pour compléter son approvisionnement.
texts.en:
Mr. Meissa D. has been is sales for 15 years after a brief stint as an apprentice driver. He focuses primarily on millet, peanuts, and black-eyed peas, which he often sells to his customers in bulk. This is the second loan application for Mr. D., age 44. He is seeking a credit of 250,000F CFA to supplement his stocks.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock up on supplies

loans.name: Hodidja

texts.en:
Hodidja is 26 years old and is married with two children who are 3 and 7 years old. Hodidja is commonly known in the business of selling shoes and this is her 6th successful year in this business. The hours of her business are from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day.

Hodidja is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company s.a in order to expand her business through adding many shoes for sale. With these additional sizes of shoes, she will hopefully earn more profits. These profits will allow her to keep reinvesting for better financial stability and enable her to start saving for the future of her children.

loans.use: To add different sizes of shoes for sale

loans.name: Phan

texts.en: Mrs. Phan V. was born in 1979 and she lives in Daeum Pou village, Takeo province. Now her position is a farmer who owns five-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. Now she has some problem because her field is infertile soil and it is far away from irrigation system and it has a lot of insect. So to improve her face production, Mrs. Phan V. is finding for a loan to purchase fertilizer, gasoline, and pesticide. Her husband, Mr. Sam Nang Men, owns a plow machine and he is also a fisherman. According this activity, they support three children, two of whom are enrolled in local public school, while the other is too small to work or study.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, gasoline, and pesticide

loans.name: Millicent Awuor

texts.en:
Millicent O. is a 39-year-old widow from Katito. She has two children, aged 12 and 16, who are both in school. Millicent has the sole responsibility of taking care of her children since her husband passed away. 

She sells materials and has been in this business for the last 15 years and has built up a huge clientele mainly consisting of tailors and just ordinary people who come to buy from her. She is applying for Kshs 10,000 as her second loan after successfully completing the first one. Millicent wants to use the money to buy bails of materials to add to her stock. She will use the profit to boost her stock and also for the upkeep of her family.

Millicent hopes to have a stable business which will enable her support her family and see her children through school.

loans.use: Buy more materials to add to her stock

loans.name: Mwanasha

texts.en:
Mwanasha is a married woman with two children who both attend school. She is married to a businessman who contributes to the family's needs. She owns a house with electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and electricity.

Mwanasha has been operating her business of selling bags of charcoal and coconuts for the last five years. She sells from door to door to her neighboring community. With the Kshs 20,000 loan, she wants to purchase five bags of charcoal and coconuts. Mwanasha faces the challenges of transportation and seasonality in her business. 

Mwanasha has another source of income: rental houses. In the future, she hopes to start a cosmetic shop. She decided to work with Yehu because of its good reputation in the community and for accessibility to sustainable financial services.

loans.use: To purchase five bags of charcoal and coconuts.

loans.name: Naramani

texts.en:
Naramani N. is a 63-year-old widow and the mother of one child. Naramani is a farmer who has been planting potatoes for sale and for her own consumption for the last twenty years.

She learned about KADET from other women who are already registered members of the organization. This will be her second loan. She is planning to spend fifty thousand shillings to prepare land for planting potatoes, which normally do well in her area due to good climatic conditions. She hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand her farming activity from small scale to commercial farming.

Naramani’s dream is build a nice house and see her child advance well academically. Despite being a window and advanced in age, N. is determined to achieve her goals.

loans.use: To prepare land for planting potatoes

loans.name: Nkai

texts.en:
Nkai M. is a 32-year-old gentleman who is married to Silantoi M.. Together they have four school-going children. Nkai has been farming for the last six years. He then sells the produce at a profit.

He learned about KADET from other members in a group already registered with KADET in his area of residence. This will be his second loan; he is planning to spend it to prepare land for planting more potatoes and also to buy some chemicals to spray those he has already planted. Potatoes have been doing well in his area due to good climatic conditions. He hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand his farming activity from small-scale to commercial farming.

Nkai’s dream is to do large-scale farming and be the best potato farmer in his area. He is a hard-working man who is determined to achieve his goals

loans.use: To prepare land for planting potatoes and buy chemicals

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
With working funds, Magdalena’s sewing business will keep on increasing, and she will be able to give pleasing service and meet the growing demands of her regular customers. Through the support of KIVA's partner, Magdalena hopes to see her family soon change the quality of their life and move away from poverty. Her long-term goal is to have a tailoring shop a few years from now so that she can give the opportunity of employment to others. 

Magdalena hopes to maintain a long-term, sustainable business. She is now requesting another ASHI loan through Kiva, this one for the much larger amount of 25,000 PHP, in order to purchase fabric cottons and three high-speed sewing machines, and to maintain her sewing business.  The capital will fund further expansion of the family ventures to support Magdalena’s dream for her children to have a decent way of life.

loans.use: To purchase fabric and sewing machines

loans.name: Jiguiseme Vi Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe JIGUISEME VI  est composé  de femmes mariées du village de Kampogosso Kafonon dans la préfecture  de San, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles, ont en moyenne 36 ans et au moins 5 enfants. Elles cultivent  de l’arachide. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les deux prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne.
TIANTIO C. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants,  au grand marché de Kimparana ville. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Kimparana. Les ventes se fond aussi dans les  marchés  environnants en détail (souvent en gros) au comptant à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
TIANTIO C. compte réaliser, après l’écoulement de sa production agricole, un bénéfice de 70.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The group JIGUISEME VI is made up of married women from the village of Kampogosso Kafonon in the prefecture of San, in the region of Ségou (the fourth administrative region of Mali). They live in traditional families and are, on average, 36 years old and have at least five children. They cultivate peanuts. In hopes of increasing the profits from their agricultural work, the members of the group decided three years ago to participate in the loan program through Soro Yiriwaso. After having properly repaid their previous loans, they are now on their third business loan. Tiantio C. plans to use her loan to buy an adequate quantity of peanut seeds, small tools, and fertilizer at the main market of Kimparana. After the winter season, the crops are stored for a length of time so that their value will increase before being sold at the main market of Kimparana. They also make their sales in neighboring markets at retail (and often at wholesale), in cash, to customers who generally come from large cities. Tiantio C. plans to earn, after the sale of her agricultural products, a profit of 30,000 to 55,000 FCFA which will be used to pay the interest on the loan and to meet daily family expenses.

Translated from French by Shannon Arnold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of fertilizers, seeds and small equipment

loans.name: Wilson Sangida

texts.en:
Wilson Sanginda N. is a 25-year-old gentleman who is married to Naitany N.; they have no child yet. Wilson is a farmer. He has been farming his own piece of land since last year.

He learned about KADET through a friend who was already registered as a member. This will be his first loan. He is planning to spend fifteen thousand to plough, ten thousand on harrowing, twenty thousand on seeds, and ten thousand on planting his five acres of wheat. He hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand his farming activity from small-scale to commercial farming.

Wilson dreams of seeing his farming project go to large scale, attain financial independence, and buy his farm machinery. He is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his goals.

loans.use: To plough and harrow his farm, and buy wheat seeds to plant

loans.name: Phoebe

texts.en:
Phoebe is married with four children, all of whom are at school, and she takes care of additional family members. Phoebe is a tailor in Busega Lubaga Division in Kampala. She plans to use this loan to buy more clothing materials and thread. She has been in this tailoring business for 10 years. She sells cooked food for additional income. 

She operates her business from the shop and pays a monthly rent of 45000 Ugandan shillings. Her customers are people around the area. She works six days a week and depends on this job for a living. Her business challenges are thieves and the rainy season, because she works in a place which is prone to floods. 

Phoebe resides in and rents a two-roomed house and family has access to electricity but no piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees, food and rent.

loans.use: To buy more clothing materials and thread

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Svetlana

texts.en: Svetlana M. works as a nurse in the village of Vaghatin in the Sisian region. Nurses' salaries are very low in the country, and a family of 5 simply can not exist on it. With the help of her father-in-law, she keeps bees and cultivates the land (grain growing). Both industries are very dependent on nature and are not always profitable. To diversify and develop her household economy, Svetlana plans to buy some livestock.

loans.use: buying livestock

loans.name: Yeredon (Se Respecter) Group

texts.fr:
Yeredon est un regroupement de femmes du quartier Koulikoro de Koutiala qui vivent dans de grandes familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents. Elles ont en moyenne 35 ans, sont mariées et mères d’au moins 3 enfants.
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers, les habillements,  l’huile  et certaine d’entre elle fait la couture. 
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a 2 ans. Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt de groupe et tous les prêts précédents  ont été bien remboursés. 
Sanata Famanta, qui est un membre du groupe fait de la couture homme et femme.  Elle est très appréciée et sollicitée  par ses clients.  
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, du fil pour la couture et  la broderie, des aiguilles et toutes sortes et bien d’autres matériels pour son activité. 
Elle se procure du matériel au marché de Madina coura. Elle à sont atelier  de couture bien équipé à la maison où elle habite et a une clientèle diverse et variée. 
Tandis que Les autres membres du groupe comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 180 000FCFA  chacune au  cours de ce cycle Sanata Famanta compte réaliser 200 000FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille les charges d’électricité lier à son activité. 
Elle ambitionne renforcer ce partenariat avec  Soro Yiriwaso pour pouvoir acquérir d’autres machines.
texts.en:
Yeredon is a women’s group in the Koulikoro quarter of Koutiala. The women live in large traditional families with their husbands, children and other relatives. They are 35 years old on average and are married with at least 3 children. This group of women is involved in the sale of various products, such as clothes and oil, and some of them make clothes. In order to expand their business, the group’s members decided to partner with Soro Yiriwaso two years ago and are now on their fifth loan, having successfully repaid all previous ones. Sanata Famanta, who is a member of the group, makes clothes for men and women. She is highly appreciated and sought-after by her customers. She aims to use her loan in order to purchase sewing and embroidery thread, needs and other materials necessary for her work. She has her own well-equipped dressmaking studio at her home, she purchases her goods from the Madina market and sells her wares to a varied customer base. Whereas the other members of the group each aim to generate an average monthly profit of 180 00 FCFA, Sanata Famanta envisages generating 200 000 FCFA. As well as repaying the loan, the women will use some of their revenue to see to their families’ needs and the electricity costs associated with her business. She would like to strengthen her relationship with Soro Yiriwaso in order to purchase more sewing machines.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase sewing materials

loans.name: Elise

texts.en:
Elise is 30 years old and is married with three children who are 1, 2 and 4 years old. Elise is well-known in the business of selling meat and this is his third successful year in this business. The hours of his business are from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day.

Elise is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company and this loan will hopefully allow him to expand his business through purchasing a large quantity of meat for sale. With this quantity, he will earn more profits which, in turn, will allow him to start creating some other sources of income and continue to provide enough care for his family.

loans.use: To buy a large quantity of meat to sell

loans.name: Maha

texts.en:
Maha is a young mother from Bethlehem. She is a teacher and the mother of three children. Maha has a B.A. degree and started working as a teacher one year ago. Her husband is a handyman who doesn't have a stable job. 

Maha's husband owns a small piece of land, so she decided to start a small business selling flowers and fruits. She plans to buy seedings to start growing flowers and, maybe, trees. 

Maha wants to use the returns from this business as a second source of income.  In the future, she hopes to save some money to expand her business and save for her three children's higher education.

Maha's husband, Ahmed, appears in the picture with one of their sons.

loans.use: Purchase seedlings

loans.name: Reina

texts.en:
Reina is a hard-working entrepreneur determined to improve her family's standard of living. She joined Kiva partner ASHI in 2005 to gain access to loans to fund her entrepreneurial dreams. The first few loans she received enabled her to support the family’s fish-selling business and sewing business. The profit from these businesses has been the main source of family income. She is now requesting another ASHI loan through Kiva for a much larger amount of 27,000 PHP to purchase more fish to sell and to support the sewing business. The capital will fund further expansion of the family ventures and support her dream that her children will complete college degrees and find good jobs. Reina hopes to maintain long-term sustainable businesses. During the course of her membership in ASHI, she has been a model member dedicated to managing her family’s business.  

Her future goal is to purchase vehicles for her husband and expand the territory of their fish-selling business to other surrounding neighborhoods. By owning her own transportation, Reina will save time and money. With her hard work, focus, and determination, Reina is hopeful that her businesses will continue to be more productive and improve the overall standard of living of her family.

loans.use: To purchase fish to sell and to support the maintenance of her sewing business.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose N. lives in the Kyebando neighborhood of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has three children, who are in school, and also takes care of  her parents. Rose has a business selling tomatoes. She has been in this business for four years and works 6 days a week. She is requesting a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to  buy more boxes of  tomatoes.

Business challenges for Rose include transportation. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to earn more profit for her family. She Joined MCDT to acquire additional capital. Rose lives in a home that she rents. She does not have access to electricity or piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, rent, and food 

About MCDT SACCO:  This loan is administered by MCDT SACCO, a savings and credit institution that uses the Grameen Bank model of solidarity lending  MCDT's cooperative structure also affords clients the opportunity to own shares of the organization and benefit from its financial performance.  The mission of MCDT SACCO is to provide sustainable financial services to the lower strata of Uganda's poor, especially women, for their economic and social development. For more on MCDT SACCO, please see our partner page at http://www.kiva.org/partners/112, and join our lending team, Friends of MCDT SACCO, at http://www.kiva.org/team/friends_of_mcdt_sacco

loans.use: to  buy more boxes  tomatoes

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia O. is 27-years-old. She is single and the mother of one child, aged four. She has a cereal store that she has been running for the last six years on a busy street in Narok Town.

She learned about KADET from other women who are already registered as clients. This will be her second loan. She is planning to increase her stock of maize. With the profits she hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, she plans to open another shop and create employment for other people. Also this being the season for harvesting maize and wheat, she is hoping to buy more stock to sell later when the price and demand are high.

Her future dream is to be able to build her own store and her own house. Lydia believes she is hard working and only needs the resources to attain her goals.

loans.use: To buy stocks of maize, wheat and beans.

loans.name: Danaya (La Confiance) Group

texts.fr:
Danaya est un regroupement de femmes de Koutiala qui se connaissent bien et  qui  vivent dans de grandes familles traditionnelles quartier Hamdallaye  avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents. Elles ont en moyenne 42 ans, sont mariées et mères d’au moins 5 enfants.
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels, les produits cosmétiques, les habillements,  les légumes, l’atiéké etc. 
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a 6 ans. Elles sont à leur treizième prêt de groupe et tous les prêts précédents  ont été bien remboursés. 
Astan Cissé est un membre du groupe qui vend des fruits et légumes (igname, manioc, cacao, banane plantain et beaucoup d’autres).  
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, des légumes par l’intermédiaire de son mari chauffeur. Elle se procure  des légumes à Abidjan (la capitale de la république de Côte d’Ivoire). Elle vend les légumes au comptant et en gros à la maison à une clientèle composée exclusivement de femmes. 
Tandis que Les membres du groupe Danaya comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 112 000FCFA  chacune au  cours de ce cycle Astan Cissé compte réaliser 140 000FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille. 
Elles souhaitent voir renforcer ce partenariat avec Soro Yiriwaso pour   augmenter son fond de commerce.
texts.en:
Danaya is a group of women from Koutiala who know each other well and who live in large traditional families in the Hamdallaye district with their husbands, children and other relataives. On average, they are 42 years old, married and the mothers of at least 5 children. This group of women sells various articles such as cosmetic products, clothing, vegetables, atiéké (cassava couscous) etc. To increase the size of their businesses, the members decided to join SoroYiriwaso’s loan program six years ago. This is their third group loan and all previous loans have been fully repaid. Astan Cissé is a group member who sells fruits and vegetables (yams, manioc, cocoa, plantain banana and many others). She intends to use her loan to buy vegetables through the intermediary of her driver husband. She buys the vegetables at Abidjan (the capital of the Republic of the Ivory Coast). She sells the vegetables for cash and wholesale at her home to a clientele composed excusively of women. While the members of the Danaya group expect to earn an average profit of 112,000 CFA each during this cycle, Astan Cissé expects to earn 140,000 CFA. As well as repaying the loans, they use part of their income to provide for their families’ everyday expenses. They would like to see this partnership with Soro Yiriwaso strengthened so as to increase their working capital.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of vegetables

loans.name: Hamidulo

texts.en:
Hamidulo is married and has 4 children. His wife helps him with his business selling sunflower seeds in the market. He started this business 18 years ago. Previously he worked as a driver and his salary was not enough to cover their expenses, so he decided to start his own business. Hamidulo saw that it would be a good opportunity to be independent and run this business. Hamidulo is requesting a loan of 6500 Somoni to purchase merchandise and supply a greater assortment of products. He and his family thank you for the support that you give him. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase addition foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Ilhomjon

texts.en:
A. Ilhomjon is 32 years old and married. His wife is the one who works in their grocery. The plans that he has for his family are to improve their living conditions and to prepare his two children for a profession. Ilhomjon has had the grocery store for 12 years; he started it with his own resources through his work. He wants to increase the sales of new products preferred by his clients. Thanks to loans from IMON International, Ilhomjon will meet his economic plans by purchasing products such as bread, tinned goods, sweets, and juices to grow his revenue.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase additional foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Tursunoy

texts.en:
B. Tursunoy is 57 years old. She is married and the loving mother of 6 children. Tursunoy, together with her husband, produces national chests for saving the dowry of brides. The national chests in Tajikistan are very colorful. They are made of wood. Mihri has been in this business for 23 years already. The stability of the business allows her to have income and ensure the family has the possibility of improving their living conditions. Because of high demand for her products now, Tursunoy is requesting a loan in the amount of 7000 Somoni in order to purchase raw materials for producing chests. Tursunoy thanks all lenders who are giving her a chance to get ahead.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase raw material for producting chests

loans.name: Sadullo

texts.ru: Абдуллоев Саъдулло проживает в районе Шахритус. Возраст, 55 лет. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Образование среднее. Более 6 лет занимается растениеводством. Арендует не большой земельный участок, где сажает дыню и арбуз. В этом ему помогают дети и жена. Кредит берет для закупа минеральных удобрений.
texts.en:
Sadullo A., 55, lives in Shakhritus district. He is married and has 5 children. For more than six years, Mr. A. has been growing watermelons and honeydews on a small parcel of land he rents. Mr. A.'s wife and children help him farm the land. This loan Mr. A. will use to purchase mineral fertilizer.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Khudoinazar

texts.en:
K. Khudoinazar is 44 years old. He and his wife have raised 4 children. For 16 years Khudoinazar has been involved in manufacturing wooden doors and window frames. His elder son helps him in the business. Khudoinazar is respected and known in the neighborhood as a real master, which brings him clientele. The business is stable and generates the main income for the family. 

Today Khudoinazar needs to purchase raw materials like wood, plywood, flake board and other supplies for his business. Also he is planning to improve the working conditions of the business. Therefore, he requests a loan of 7500 Somoni. Khudoinazar thanks all of you for supporting him and for your trust.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase wood, plywood, flake board and other supplies

loans.name: Pauline

texts.en:
Pauline W. G. is twenty-nine years old. She is married and has two children, aged nine years old and three and a half years old. 

Pauline hawks clothes at the Kihunguru area in Thika town. Thika is the region in Kenya known for production of pineapples. She sells clothes like shirts, trousers, and pullovers to the local people. She says that this business is profitable and the only major challenge she has is the high prices for clothes, which makes the resale price higher. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

Pauline is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more shirts, jackets, trousers and pullovers to expand her business. In the future, she hopes to have a very well-established business. She describes herself as hardworking and innovative.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for resale

loans.name: Sona

texts.en: Sona A. is married and has 2 children. Sona has been managing a wholesale fabric shop since 2008. Her fabric is very popular. To keep up with her clients' demand, Sona needs to replenish her stock and purchase more fabric.

loans.use: Purchasing fabric

loans.name: Mobibi

texts.en:
M. Mobibi is 53 years old. She is married with 4 adorable children. Mobibi has been able to combine her love of children with a successful business selling kid’s clothing at a busy market in Dushanbe. Mobibi currently has one sales place at the market. Eventually, she would like to open a store in a permanent facility. She has requested a loan of 5400 Somoni to help purchase new clothing inventory.

loans.use: To purchase additional clothing to sell

loans.name: Daler

texts.en:
R. Daler is 28 years old. He has lived for 5 years with the mother of his three children. His parents taught him the art of cultivating grapes, and he has always tried to sow his hectares so that he would have a crop in every season. He says that agriculture requires much patience and luck, because there are seasons where there is no profit and other seasons that are very good, but either way, profitable or not, he has to keep sowing. Daler asked for a loan of 13,000 Somoni that will be invested in his crop supplies. Be an important part of the growth of Daler’s business.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Aggrey

texts.en:
Aggrey is a 48 year-old man who sells glass to contractors in the area.  He has been in this business for 7 years and his biggest challenge is local competition.  He is married and has 5 children: 3 daughters and 2 sons.

Aggrey plans to use the 50,000 Kenya Shilling loan to open a different shop to sell glass.

In the future, he hopes to open an even bigger shop.  Aggrey describes himself as hardworking.

loans.use: To open a different shop to sell glass to contractors

loans.name: Khitam

texts.en:
Khitam and her family run a restaurant in Jabalia, a city in the Gaza Strip. Khitam is the mother of five sons and two daughters. 

Khitam and her husband, Mohammad, have been fixing a few things and replacing old equipment in the restaurant. They still need to replace the old oven, so Khitam came to Faten and received a $1,500 loan for this purpose.

Khitam, her husband, and children are known for their honesty and good manners. In the future, Khitam and her husband plan to have a bigger restaurant that serves seafood if the returns from the current restaurant increase as expected.

In the photo, Khitam's husband, Mohammad, is working in the restaurant.

loans.use: Purchasing ovens

loans.name: Abra

texts.en:
Madame Abra T. A. is 36 years old. She is married to another merchant and they live in Lomé, Togo with their one child. 

Madame A. sells pagnes, beautifully colored traditional Togolese cloths. She has been selling pagnes since 1999. She sells them by walking through her neighborhood, carrying the pagnes stacked on her head. This is a lucrative business, given that most women in Togo use pagnes as skirts or dresses, baby wraps, head wraps, or cloth for making other clothing. She is now taking her first loan from WAGES of 300,000 CFA in order to purchase 20 more pagnes to sell.

loans.use: To purchase pagnes, a traditional Togolese cloth

loans.name: Mirna María

texts.es:
La Sra. Mirna O. tiene su negocio de venta de productos de plástico ubicado en el mercado la estación, tiene su negocio bien establecido y realiza sus compras 2 veces por semana en Managua, donde compra su producto al por mayor y así obtiene mayores ingresos.

Este crédito lo solicita para la compra de bolsas plásticas, vasos, cucharas, platos desechables, entre otros. Cabe mencionar que la Señora O. M., está agradecida con los créditos que le ha brindado CEPRODEL, porque anteriormente ha hecho uso de los créditos y han incrementado su capital de trabajo y mejorado su nivel de vida.

Hoy, una vez más confía que su crédito será otorgado satisfactoriamente y así mejorará su condición familiar.
texts.en:
Sra. Mirna María O. M. has a well-established business at the station market. She travels twice a week to Managua to buy her inventory in bulk so that she can generate more income. The loan she is requesting will be used to buy plastic bags, glasses, spoons, disposable plates, and other products. It should be mentioned that Sra. Mirna is grateful for the loans that CEPRODEL has provided because they have increased her operating capital and improved her standard of living.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase plastic bags, glasses, spoons, disposable plates, and other products

loans.name: Askarali

texts.ru: Шарипов Аскарали проживает в районе Шахритус. Возраст, 28 лет. Женат, имеет 2 детей. Образование среднее. Более 6 лет занимается растениеводством. Арендует земельный участок, где выращивает овощи для продажи. Кредит берет для закупа минеральных удобрений, чтобы получить хороший урожай. На полученную прибыль он хочет расширить свой бизнес.
texts.en:
Askarali S. lives in the Shahrituz district. He is 28 years old, married and has 2 children. He has a secondary education. Askarali has been involved in agriculture for over 6 years.
